utterances: Right, right...
...you know, all that kind of thing.
You could do - it was do it yourself.
It was whatever, anything goes.
And I think that's what was so great about Nirvana.
Let's squeeze one more call in here if we can.
This is Franklin from South Bend, Indiana.
Franklin, welcome.
Hi, there.
Hi.

My biggest memory of MTV is actually not the music portion of it but the reality portion, and that was ""The Real World."" I grew up in a very rural part of Indiana, so there wasn't a lot of multiculturalism.
And so when I went to high - when I went to college, that was the San Francisco season, and it just opened me up to an incredible world that I wasn't even aware of.
And the whole season with Pedro and introducing homosexuality to the nation in a much different light than what I grew up viewing, and his whole story line.
And then him dying of AIDS and then President Clinton saying that, now nobody in the United States can say that they weren't affected by somebody that died of AIDS.
I can just remember watching the tribute special to him, just...
Franklin, I've got to interrupt you only because there's another piece of tape I want to play before we get out of here.
Thank you very much for the phone call.
This is 1992, the beginning of reality TV on MTV.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""THE REAL WORLD: SAN FRANCISCO"")
I'm HIV-positive.
When Pedro told me he's HIV-positive, I was just like, no, not him.
I like this guy and I don't want him to have to suffer.
Our time is up, Matt Pinfield, and it's been a wonderful conversation.
But would you say that MTV will be remembered more for the music or for its impact on reality TV?
Exactly.
It's really, I mean, what they say is that Titan could be like a frozen snapshot of what the Earth was like when it was very, very young.
And Titan sort of stayed frozen in time.
So, yeah.
What do you think, Eric?
Gosh, I don't know.

I think it will be remembered for both things, because it changed the way people listened to and looked at music and it actually - I know because I was in the music department helping pick the videos and creating buzz clips.
It helped break so many artists and make artists go from obscurity into the stratosphere.
And it also introduced reality TV, which has, of course, now exploded and you've got competition shows.
You got a show like, you know, the last call we got, I have to agree with him.
I think it was great that people learned about AIDS and that, you know, people with a small-town mind that didn't want to face it or understand it, they finally got to see it.
It was a very important thing.
So I think it will be remembered for both, Tony, to be honest.
You were a big part of that.
Happy birthday to MTV.
And happy birthday to you for your part in doing it.
Matt Pinfield, host, ""120 Minutes,"" which comes on the last Saturday of every month on MTV2, joining us from our bureau in New York.
Tomorrow, army tanks in Syria continue to pound anti-government protesters.
We'll talk about what, if anything, the US can do about it.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Tony Cox in Washington.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Alex Cohen.
By now, you've heard the buzz or lack thereof about bees.
Huge numbers of them are dying.
No one's quite certain why.
This is both wild bees and the domesticated kind that many farmers count on to pollinate their crops.
But no such problem on the campus of the University of Houston, where they've just discovered more than 100,000 bees living behind the bricks in a wall of the engineering building.
Yesterday the school's director of Grounds and Custodial Services, Alex Alexander, was on site overseeing the removal of the hive without killing any bees.
The trick, he explained to us, is to find the queen bee behind the brick wall.
We were able to locate the source of the hive by temperature readings through the wall.
Once we established about where the nest was, which is about 40 feet off the ground, he drilled holes through the brick and was able to insert a camera.
Then we just started slowly removing the outside brick wall, brick by brick, and we started removing the hive by hand.
How much do you think this is costing the University of Houston as opposed to something like, say, a gas bomb?
And I don't even want to think about the e-mails we're going to get for suggesting that.
But really, these are the kinds of things you have to think about, aren't they?
It was never a consideration that we would kill the bees using some kind of pesticide.
We still would have the organic matter, the honey, the carcasses of the bees, inside that building.
So we haven't added a significant amount of cost.
Is it costing us a little bit more?
Yes.
I've read that the honey was actually oozing through the wall.
Is that - what does honey look like coming through the wall?
How do you know it's honey?
Well, it looked like pancake syrup leaking out of the - leaking out of a hole in the base of the wall.
What are you going to do with these bees?
Where are they going to go?
Well, we're - we've so far successfully captured the queen and the brood and the - a lot of the honey.
We're going to relocate them on campus.
We have some secluded wooded areas that'll be a perfect place for the bees to be.
You know, we look at this not as a pest control issue as much as that these bees live here on campus.
They were just in the wrong place.
And we're going to put them in the place that they need to be.
Because without these bees, we wouldn't have the flowers, we wouldn't have the plants and the trees that the students and the faculty and the rest of the community enjoy so much.
So you're in this process today, this afternoon, as we're speaking.
Are you going to be done by the time our program goes on the air tomorrow?
We will be done with the removal and the relocation, yes.
Well, Alex Alexander, good luck.
I don't suppose you're going to put out the University of Houston honey or...
Absolutely.
We're thinking...
You are.
...we're going to put them in little jars as kind of a little novelty with U of H logo on there and the text: University of Houston the only place to bee.
I thought it was a good idea.
We've got some folks who are getting a chuckle out of that.
You're going to have it in the campus bookstore?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, our bee expert is telling us we've got probably about five gallons worth of honey.
So we're not quite sure what we're going to do with them, but it's U of H honey.
We're going to keep it here on campus.
I'm sure we'll do something clever with it.
Alex Alexander, director of Custodial Services at the University of Houston.
Alex, thank you.
Thank you.
Mormons are also processing a decision by the Boy Scouts of America to lift a ban on openly gay troop leaders.
The move came as a blow to conservative religious organizations like the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Qin Monson is a Mormon.
He's also a former Boy Scout, the father of a Scout and a political science professor at Brigham Young University.
He spoke to me from BYU Radio in Provo, Utah and explained Mormons' deep roots in the Boy Scout movement.
Well, the Boy Scouts of America has been the official program for young men in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints within the United States of America for over a hundred years.

So the church took the Boy Scout program and decided that its values and mission aligned closely enough with that of the church's program for young men that they just wholesale adopted it and have had local congregations sponsor or charter Scout troops.
And basically, if you are a young Mormon male, you join the Boy Scouts.
And in those church-sponsored troops, is there teaching of church doctrine?
Is it purely secular, or is there some overlap?
The Beau Rivage Casino in Biloxi, Mississippi, was a 71,000 square foot floating gambling hall with a 1,700 room hotel and restaurant complex on adjacent land.
Hurricane Katrina lifted the casino and dropped it on land, and the storm's winds and water devastated the rest of the resort.
MGM Mirage, which owns the Beau Rivage, quickly announced plans to rebuild, and the day after the storm the company opened a recovery center in the parking lot of the casino to assist employees.
Mike Davis used to be the assistant director of convention sales at the Beau Rivage.
He's still employed by the casino but for now as a jack-of-all-trades.
Earlier this weekend, he joined us from his home in Ocean Springs, Mississippi, to tell us what kind of work he's been doing since Katrina hit.
Well, I--jack-of-all-trades is a pretty good handle for it.
We have set up a distribution center for our employees, and I've been kind of out there just manning the distribution center with a few other people that work at Beau Rivage.
We've set up water stations.
We've set up health-screening areas.
We've set up a job employment center.
And we also have a paycheck distribution center.
And I'm kind of a floater.
I float around, make sure that everyone's got water, make sure everyone's enjoying themselves while they're standing in line or waiting to speak to a counselor.
Enjoying themselves in line.
We try to make it fun for everybody but obviously it's a very serious time for us.
Paycheck distribution--everybody still being paid?
They are.
Our company has stepped to the plate and said that they're going to pay our employees for 90 days.
We're going to have ongoing health benefits for those 90 days, as well.
So every two weeks, people come down to our distribution center, they either pick up their paycheck or, if they have direct deposit, that'll be deposited directly into their account.
